abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            developments substantial. Lessons convey the following. By
            and large, within Africa, a Road Fund, financed from user
            fees is an important way to ensure the availability of funds
            for maintenance. In this case, even when the government
            lacked budgetary resources, the Road Fund continued to be
            funded. However, mobilizing local counterpart funding in
            rural areas for road maintenance is difficult, where the
            overhead costs for community mobilization (fees to NGOs) are
            high and are likely to make replicability difficult.
            Therefore, additional means of financing rural road
            maintenance should be considered. Moreover, when a Road Fund
            is introduced, the responsibility of each agency should be
            clearly outlined in order to avoid potential disagreements.
            Whereas the Road Fund did provide funds for civil works,
            conflicts arose concerning how the funds should be managed,
            and which agency should contract the work.  In addition,
            small and medium contractors (PMEs) encountered difficulties
            in the development of the new maintenance system; instead,
            it would have been useful to develop a system of assistance
            for PMEs during preparation. It is recommended to accompany
            the privatization of road maintenance activities, with
            widespread training programs, to quickly build up the
            necessary capacity in the construction industry.
